Award.AwardTitle: DIP: Collaborative Research: Impact of Adaptive Interventions on Student Affect, Performance, and Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A major factor influencing learning is students' emotions and their general affective state. Given the pivotal role that affect plays in learning activities it is not surprising that there has been a good deal of interest in developing affect-aware technologies. The overwhelming majority of this work, however, has focused on modeling affect, i.e., designing computational models capable of inferring how students are feeling while interacting with an Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS). While modeling of affect is a critical first step in providing adaptive support tailored to students' affective needs, very little work exists on systematically exploring the impact of affective interventions on students' performance, learning, affect and attitudes, i.e., how to respond to students' emotions such as frustration, anxiety, boredom, and hopelessness as they arise. The research fills this gap by analyzing the value of tailoring different types of interventions to negative affective states for individual students and groups of students.

The project has two main goals. First, it addresses how to respond to negative student emotion (e.g., frustration, anxiety, boredom) in computer-based learning environments through a variety of interventions. Some correspond to specially-designed digital characters, integrated into the learning environment, which are intended to act like students' learning companions. These agents support students through (a) non-verbal behaviors (e.g., having the characters express empathy in response to student frustration), (b) messages targeting students' cognitive and meta-cognitive skills, as well as motivation and affect. Other interventions involve supporting collaboration between students to mitigate negative emotional states when detected. The impact of these interventions are investigated through a series of eight experiments with a total of 800 students. These experiments help to unveil general prescriptive principles to address student affect.

The second goal accomplished by this research is that the experiments provide valuable data to continue to extend and validate existing models of emotion. Specifically, the project triangulates and integrates a complex space of partially overlapping models and constructs of affect in learning (i.e. emotions, attitudes, incoming moods, motivation, engaged use or misuse of software). The project refines several well-established models, in particular the control-value theory of emotions to provide a more stable theoretical framework for the field of emotions in educational software.

This research is unique and ground breaking, as few researchers have targeted students' emotion in classrooms, gathered fine grained data on emotions during learning, or assessed the impact of specific affective treatments on a moment-to-moment basis. Students using the tutoring systems have already shown statistically significant gains and learning outcomes, as well as increased positive affect and attitudes. The new affective interventions will greatly increase the broad impact of these systems.
This research is developing: (1) prescriptive principles about how to respond to student affect; (2) new understanding about the impact of cognitive, affective, and meta-cognitive interventions on emotions and learning; (3) new understanding about individual differences in learning, unveiling the extent to which emotion, cognitive abilities, and gender impact learning; (4) instruction that is sensitive to individual differences; and (5) refined theories of student emotion.

This research is also: (1) increasing participation in mathematics of underrepresented populations (women and minorities) who often avoid STEM careers; (2) creating broad access to web-based technologies that help to engage more students by addressing their affective and social needs; and (3) addressing the one-size-fits-all approach to education, by responding to individual student needs with alternative representations of content and pathways through which material is presented.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research analyzed the value of tailoring different types of interventions to negative affective states or individual students as they use a math tutoring system. Emotions that are recognized by this tutor include frustration, anxiety, boredom, confidence, interest, excitement.

The main goal of the project was to learn how to respond to negative student emotion such as frustration, anxiety, and boredom in computer-based learning environments. The project used a variety of interventions involving specially-designed digital characters designed to act like student learning companions that are integrated into the learning environment. Other interventions involved supporting collaboration between students to mitigate detected negative emotional states. The impact of these interventions are investigated through a series of eight experiments involving a hundred students each, which contribute to understanding of general prescriptive principles to address student affect.

Secondary project goals were (1) for the experiments to provide valuable data to continue to extend and validate how to assess student emotion as they interact in a technology learning environment, and (2) to identify prescriptive models of student emotion and how to create them. Specifically, the project triangulated and integrated a complex space of partially overlapping models and constructs of affect in learning (i.e. emotions, attitudes, incoming moods, motivation, engaged use or misuse of software). The project refined several well-established models, in particular, the control-value theory of emotions to provide a more stable theoretical framework for the field of emotions in educational software.

This project made contributions to: (1) prescriptive principles about how to respond to student affect; (2) new understanding about the impact of cognitive, affective, and meta-cognitive interventions on emotions and learning; (3) new understanding about individual differences in learning, unveiling the extent to which emotion impacts learning; (4) instruction that is sensitive to individual differences; and (5) refined theories of student emotion.

The Learning Environment. This research was conducted within an established intelligent mathematics tutor for grades 5-12 called MathSpring.  This tutoring environment has been used by thousands of students in the United States, has generated improved learning gains over control groups, and produced significantly higher gains on state-standard exams compared to control groups. The MathSpring tutor includes a cognitive student model that assesses individual students’ knowledge and effort exerted and adapts the choice of problem accordingly. The system also provides a variety of individualized assistance, including hints and explanations, tutorial videos, and animated worked-out examples. To expand the range of scaffolding offered, we have been working to incorporate support to alleviate negative affect when it occurs, based on a metacognitive intervention we now describe.

Using log data to determine student affect. Given the pivotal role played by affect and motivation in education in both short-term performance outcomes and long-term career choices, there is growing interest in creating educational technologies that can recognize and respond to student affect.   To continue to research interventions that respond to student affect, we need to continue refining our ways to effectively and efficiently detect how students are feeling as they use the tutoring system. Emotions are highly dependent on context and are expressed in behaviors. Thus, when designing models to assess student emotion, it is essential to empirically understand which factors impact student emotional states, what comprises an emotional state, and how the student reveals their affective state in terms of subsequent actions and behaviors. Many models might appear to detect effect in a highly accurate way until the software is used in different school settings, where they start to “fall apart,” and fail to accurately predict students emotion. The ability to effectively transfer across school settings is one of the current challenges of Affect-Sensitive software.
